climbs.name: Wimp Roof
climbs.fa: Tom McLeod, Tedd Thompson, Pete Takeda

content.description: Easy climbing leads to a big roof. Same start as Whimper, go slightly rightÂ at third bolt and climb under the roof. Powerful moves and good foot work.
Follow the long corner just left of Rock Hudson(11a sport).  The crack is small, so plan accordingly.  Surprisingly hard finish as you work right at the top of the corner.
content.location: The long corner just a few cracks to the left of Rock Hudson(11a sport).  See beta pic.

content.description: Clip the first 3 bolts of Wimp Roof and split left, clipping 2 more bolts on the way to the chains. Fun climbing with an exciting finish.
content.location: When you first get to East Carbody, look up for a bolted roof split by a hand crack. That's Wimp Roof. Start up that climb and fork left at the 3rd bolt.

content.description: Ascend an obvious dihedral, then follow the crack to climber's left about 30' up. The crack widens to perfect hands near the top, making for an exciting finish.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #3 BD Camalot
content.location: About 30' to the right of the bolt line for Holiday in Cambodia

content.description: Typical Black Cliffs dihedral with a tricky finish through the bulge.  Definitely thought provoking.
content.location: Just right of Citizens Against Spiders.

climbs.name: Tin Man
climbs.fa: Matt Fritz, Bruce Budell, Steve Young

content.description: This route never really gives you much room to breath. The start moves through crimps and rounded off sidepulls leading into an easy runout between bolts 3 and 4 before leaving you empty handed on a blank face between bolts 4 and 5...Oh and the cracks on either side of the column are off limits. Good luck!
content.location: You'll know this route by the L shaped hangers on the bolts. It's about 100 feet from Wimp Roof and to the right of Macabre Roof. Scramble up the detached blocks to the start. Mind the pile of feces below.

content.description: This is the third bolted route from the head of East Car Body.  Although this route is fairly short it is a bold lead with widely spaced bolts.  The crux falls around the second bolt.  This route requires good foot work, is thought provoking and you may even get a pump on due to the small side pulls and crimps. Sustained and technical climbing until the third bolt where the route eases up with large jugs to the chains.
content.protection: Three bolts to chain anchors.  A bold lead with little to no opportunity for supplemental gear placement where you want it. Like several other BC routes, missing the second bolt would likely result in a ground fall.  However, this route can be easily toproped from the Boys-r-Blue chains and is definitely worth checking out.
content.location: The third bolted route at the head of East Car Body Just right of Boys-r-Blue (5 bolts).  Scrabble up the large flat blocks at the base to start.

content.description: Starts on top of a short pillar.  Work the dihedral up to the cool flake-like feature.  Super fun!
content.location: A few cracks left of The Industrial Age (sport).  See beta pic.

content.description:
Climb low-5th class, broken rock to a ledge and the first bolt at 15-20'. Clipping this with a long draw will reduce drag. From here, follow the obvious line up increasingly better rock to the 5th and last bolt just above the small roof. Clip this and move straight up, pulling on pockets and edges of varying degrees of positivity to the chains.

The route is a bit contrived as it is possible to use the left arete after the last bolt to bring the route down to .10b as listed in the book. This

involves moving into what I thought to be dangerous fall potential above a broken column top.

If the starting bit of rock and the upper contrivances are disregarded, this thing is pretty good. It protects well (when climbed directly) and the boulder problem at the crux is fun and on great rock.
content.location:
First bolted line left of

Macabre Roof

. Look for the first bolt above the ledge about 15' from the deck.

content.description: Climb the obvious column just right of Ambition is Critical (the column that looks like it shouldn't still be standing).  The first bolt is a rusty 1/4", but there's only 3 bolts on the route so you might as well clip it.  Once you get the beta dialed in it's climbable.  Exciting finish... Just give in to the whipper and hope the column still stands.
content.location: Right of Ambition is Critical, you have to scramble up some rocks to start the route and belay.

content.description: This is the Hand/Fist width crack a few feet to the right of The Cleaning Lady and Dirty Luck. It shares anchors with those routes. I think I only placed #2s and #3s.
This route starts out relatively easy, but the crack gets pretty thin about halfway up. It would be pretty hairy without the lone bolt up there. Good quality, with moves that will make you think.
content.protection: Small gear and one bolt. Bring the smallest cams you've got, it gets pretty thin up there! Two chain anchors
content.location: Just left of Basalt Somersault. Look for a single bolt up where the crack thins out.

content.description: A fun sport route, this route has a good variety of movement. It starts out with some technical moves off the deck, then some pulling hard on big slopey holds up the arete, followed by some technical stemming back in the dihedral.
content.location: Left of Eyeless in Gaza, right of The Industrial Age.

content.description: If you're willing to put up with a junky start, there's a nice left leaning finger and hands crack just right of Whaleback Crack. I recommend starting as for Whaleback crack and then breaking right onto this route vs starting in the next dihedral over. The crack starts very thin, then turns to big/ off fingers, with some hand size pods closer to the anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 2". Micro cams and medium sized nuts very useful for establishing into initial thin crack.
content.location: One route to the right of Whaleback Crack. Shares anchors with Whaleback Crack.

content.description: The first half of this route features easy stemming between good features.  Somewhere around the 3rd bolt the route traverses left and gets a little tricky.  It's all there, but I found it a little hard to figure out the right sequence.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  The second bolt might be slightly runout from the first, but the climbing is easy.
content.location: Towards the right end of the wall, just left of the bolted Wimp Roof.

content.description:
This route climbs the double dihedral and roof directly below the anchors for The Pansy, merging with it at the 3rd bolt.  This adds some fun jamming and tricky stemming, you get to bypass the rather easy and boring start of the original Pansy, and you still get to climb the Pansy's crux.  Highly recommended!

Start in the dihedral using a nice handcrack on the right until you reach the roof.  Pull the roof using finger locks and smeary stemming.

After the fun climbing up to and over the roof, climb some loose terrain without protection until you reach the 3rd bolt of The Pansy.  Finish with the tough (interesting) part of The Pansy.
content.protection: Hand size gear for the dihedral, small stuff to protect the roof, and two bolts.  2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Starts directly below the anchors for The Pansy.

content.description: Start just right of Gargling Vinegar, passing 3 bolts to the obvious large ledge below the roof.  Clip the last bolt and venture out left on exposed rock to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains, optional supplementary gear
content.location: Just right of Gargling Vinegar

content.description: This climb features beautiful double hand cracks that eventually lead up to a roof, which is split in the middle by a crack. In Sandi Epeldi's book the roof is described as "a classic boulder problem in the sky", and I'd have to agree.
content.protection: This climb is very well protected and will suck up as many nuts and cams as you care to throw into it.  There is a two bolt anchor on the comfortable ledge above the roof.
content.location: This climb is located roughly in the middle of the East Carbody Canyon wall.

content.description: A smearing, stemmy sort of route with a couple thoughtful cruxy sections. The cruxes are well protected by bolts. Good footwork is Key.
content.location:
The route is between Eyeless In Gaza & The Macabre Roof. There is a detached block that forms a short chimney at the start. Rap or lower from the top.

The two routes just to the left of this are also fun(The Scream and Basalt Somersault). These are in the Epeldi Guide.

content.description: Finger Crack to chains
content.location: In between right grunge tower andÂ  curt's boot

content.description: This climb starts on big edges down low, goes up and over a bulgy section, and has a few interesting last moves before the chains. This is one of the easier bolted leads at the cliffs in my opinion.
content.location: It's towards the left side of East Car Body. Look for 4 bolts, big edges towards the bottom, and no bolted routes on either side of it for 30ft+

content.description: A fun climb up the outside of a narrow column.  Most of the route follows widely spaced jugs using fun moves. After clipping the last bolt, shorter folks will either have to dyno or use small crimps and even smaller feet to reach the finishing jug. Fun!
content.location: Located about 50 yards left of the Pansy

content.description: This is the first bolted route at the head of East Car Body.  This route is short and blowing the third clip could result in a ground fall.  Not recommended for the faint of heart or inexperienced 5.10 leaders.
content.location: This is the first route at the back of the "cove" on the east side.

content.description: Short dihedral with easy stemming up to an anchor below a roof.  A nice climb to set up as a toprope for less experienced climbers.
content.location: A little to the right of Macabre Roof.

content.description: Nice little inside corner to chains. Good pro. No distinct crux but a nice warm up.
content.location: Check out Sandy Epeldi's fine guide for pics and info.

content.description:
The business end starts off the ground. Use the pockets and small rails to gain the nice finger to hand jam crack.

This is a full value 8 that's more difficult than its neighbor, The Cleaning Lady.
content.protection:
Nuts down low and gear to 2 inches at the top of the crack.

Look for the eponymous chains above.
content.location: Near far left end of East Car Body Canyon.  Route starts two feet right of the Cleaning Lady.

content.description:
Go straight up the dihedral.  Using the outer holds lessens the rating a tad from what's in the Epeldi book.

Climbing it as a true crack definitely puts it at 5.8.  Nice double finger length to hand jams at the top of the crack.

Topping out at the chains isn't so obvious, but the hand holds are there.
content.protection:
Nuts to small cams.

Finish on the chains of Dirty Luck
content.location: Start to ten feet left of Temporary Insanity; five feet right of three small staircase blocks.

content.description: This dihedral has some fun moves and good pro.
content.location: Dihedral to the left of Holiday in Cambodia

content.description: Short climb with some fun bouldery moves. Worth checking out.
A very nice dihedral with some great stemming and smearing.
content.protection: Gear. Make sure to bring some tiny cams for the crux. Two chain anchor.
content.location: In a dihedral just right of The Scream(has one bolt up high). Left of Lichen Lunch

content.description: Start by climbing a broken pillar to a high first bolt.  Continue up a dihedral, clipping 2 more bolts, and mantle onto the ledge below the big roof. Clip your last bolt in the bottom of the roof, start traversing left on a juggy slot and snag jugs left of the bolt.  Pull the roof and mantle to the chains (crux).
content.location: Between Neon Leprechaun(10a) and Sperm Whale(11b).  See beta pic
